awd_titl_txt: Uncovering the Molecular Mechanisms of Selfish Genetic Elements
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual Merit: Advantageous genes normally persist and predominate in populations, while deleterious genes disappear. However, some non-adaptive genes have found ways to counter the forces of natural selection and infiltrate populations; these are known as selfish genetic elements or selfish genes. Such elements are able to increase in frequency and spread through populations by employing genetic mechanisms that circumvent Mendel's laws of inheritance. A fascinating case is that of the Maternal-Effect Dominant Embryonic Arrest (Medea) elements in the red flour beetle, Tribolium castaneum. Heterozygous Medea females transmit a dominant-lethal factor to hatchlings, but the lethal effect is shut down in those progeny that inherit a Medea allele from either parent. Thus, each Medea allele encodes both a maternally loaded "poison" and an "antidote" expressed in the embryo. Little is known about how such elements function. Therefore, this project is aimed at discovering the molecular mechanism responsible for Medea's selfish behavior by using genetic and genomic tools to uncover the genes involved in self-selection.  

Broader Impacts: This project will increase our understanding of how selfish genes escape natural selection and infiltrate populations. This knowledge could provide a new mechanism for transferring traits into pest populations to make them less problematic. The project includes several educational components. The PI is participating in an NSF Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (Genetic Engineering and Society: The case of transgenic pests) that is focused on training students in technologies used for manipulation of pest genomes as well as methods needed to assess the environmental and sociocultural appropriateness of specific products of these genetic manipulations. This research will be integrated directly into IGERT courses and research of IGERT graduate fellows. The project also includes activities that will provide undergraduates from underrepresented groups with an opportunity to participate in cutting-edge functional genomic research. Moreover, this research will be widely disseminated through outreach events by the PI and IGERT students to raise public awareness about the utility of transgenic technologies.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

Selfish-genetic elements are genomic DNA sequences that maintain their own existence, or even replicate, despite offering no benefit to the plants and animals that carry them. Because of this, it has long been thought that such elements could be used to push desirable traits into insect pest populations, such as making crop pests susceptible to pesticides, or making human-disease vectors (e.g. mosquitoes) unable to spread those diseases. To that end, the major goal of this project was to gain a better understanding of a unique class of selfish-genetic elements found in Tribolium beetles. These  elements only display selfish behavior when females reproduce: offspring that inherit the Medea gene live, while the remainder die. The best current hypothesis for how this may work is via a toxin/antidote mechanism in which the toxin is pre-loaded into each egg, with embryonic expression of Medea rescuing offspring that inherit the element. Our initial assays were aimed at identifying the "toxin" by looking for differences in gene expression in unfertilized eggs laid by Medea vs. non-Medea beetles. But rather than assessing gene expression in eggs from a single Medea strain and comparing to a single non-Medea strain, we analyzed expression in eggs obtained from eight geographically-distinct strains (four/genotype). However, no obvious candidate for the toxin was found. Rather, we discovered that gene expression is highly variable, even among similar genotypes. Since sequencing pre-loaded mRNAs failed to reveal a candidate, this suggests that the toxin may be a small RNA or protein. However, it is also possible that the toxin/antidote hypothesis is false.

Our next step was to mate heterozygous (M/+) Medea females with non-Medea (+/+) males, and sort the resultant offspring based on genotype, i.e. expression of a visible marker that is tightly linked to Medea. RNA was isolated from both groups at two distinct time points (~24-hours-apart), and their mRNA sequenced. This assay was designed to address two major questions: 1) do all offspring undergo similar embryonic development as hypothesized, and 2) is  death due to a neurological impairment, a hypothesis based on the fact that non-Medea (+/+) hatchlings appear uncoordinated before death. Interestingly, neither of these seems to be the case. Rather, the expression data revealed that non-Medea offspring suffer from a significant developmental delay, being approximately 24-hours behind their siblings in expression of many key genes.

This and other data gathered over the course of the project culminated in a single, testable hypothesis for how Medea elements behave selfishly. We are currently testing this hypothesis by adding a copy of the candidate Medea element to the genome of non-Medea beetles, as well as to the genome of a fly (Drosophila melanogaster). If either of these genetic manipulations results in selfish behavior, it will confirm our hypothesis and aid in the search for similar selfish-genetic elements in other species. Although we were not able to complete either gene addition during the funding cycle, work on both continues. Importantly, over the course of the project, we realized an unexpected benefit to our research. Specifically, with the invention of Cas9-mediated artificial gene drive, it is now possible to engineer almost any organism to carry one or more selfish-genetic elements. Whether such strains are designed to diminish vector-borne diseases or reduce agricultural losses, it is now possible to alter wild populations by releasing relatively small numbers of transgenic individuals. However, since we know nothing about the real world spread of these synthetic gene-drive elements, it is even more important that we gain a better understanding of naturally occurring selfish elements, as these can be useful for inferring how synthetic elements could spread both locally and globally.

 

Broader impacts 

In total, this project enabled me to train 5 graduate students, 8 undergraduate students, 4 high school students, 4 technicians and 1 postdoc in genetics, genomics, transgenics and molecular biology. The postdoc and all five graduate students also attended weekly colloquia on topics ranging from ethics and responsible innovation, to gene drive and synthetic biology. The deliberative format of colloquium improved their skills in science communication. This professional development opportunity was available to them due to the project's fit with NCSU's NSF-funded Integrated Graduate Research Traineeship Program, "Genetic Engineering and Society". Of these 5 students, 2 were members of the first IGERT cohort, while another is a member of the third, thereby gaining deep interdisciplinary training in both technical and social issues. Linkage of these projects resulted in greater participation by students (and their mentor) in public outreach events, social media, and local, national, and international meetings. For example, in 2016, two of these graduate students competed, and won first place in an international student debate on selfish-genetic elements. Through these avenues, we were able to share what we learned in our lab with a large and diverse audience, including specialized researchers and the lay public.
